tt_insn_vec.help: Portion of vector registers that is actually used. Available only for instructions belonging to a SIMD/vector instructions set (like x86 AVX)

tt_Recip_throughput.help: Average number of cycles to retire that instruction if repeated (assuming independent instructions, with no read-after-write dependency)

hint.workaround:
- Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
  * Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
 - Use vector aligned instructions:
  1) align your arrays on 64 bytes boundaries
  2) inform your compiler that your arrays are vector aligned: read your compiler manual.
<<image_vec_align>>
hint.title: Vector unaligned load/store instructions
hint.txt: Detected 4 suboptimal vector unaligned load/store instructions.

hint.title: Type of elements and instruction set
hint.txt: 6 SSE or AVX instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on double precision FP elements in vector mode (two at a time).

hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop is composed of 12 FP arithmetical operations:
 - 8: addition or subtraction
 - 4: multiply
The binary loop is loading 32 bytes (4 double precision FP elements).
The binary loop is storing 32 bytes (4 double precision FP elements).

hint.txt: Arithmetic intensity is 0.19 FP operations per loaded or stored byte.

 - AGU1 (256 bits): store address, load
 - AGU2 (256 bits): store address, load
 - FP0 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP1 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP2 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP3 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP4 (256 bits): FP store data
 - FP5 (256 bits): FP store data

expert.help: Compare the CQA-computed load/store/compute metrics with the capacity of the core. For instance if CQA computes 24 bytes in the loop in 2 cycles (that is 12 cycles per cycle) and if the core can process up to 16 bytes per cycle, that metric is 75%.
expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 2.83 cycles. At this rate:
 - 11% of peak load performance is reached (11.29 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 17% of peak store performance is reached (11.29 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.83 to 2.00 cycles (1.42x speedup).

header: 17% of peak computational performance is used (4.24 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
 - To reference allocatable arrays, use "allocatable" instead of "pointer" pointers or qualify them with the "contiguous" attribute (Fortran 2008)
 - For structures, limit to one indirection. For example, use a_b%c instead of a%b%c with a_b set to a%b before this loop
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.83 to 2.67 cycles (1.06x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- use profile-guided optimization flags of your compiler
 - hardcode most frequent values of loop bounds by adding specialized paths.:
  *  For instance, replace do i=1,n foo(i) with:
select case (n)
  case (4): do i=1,4 foo(i)
  case (6): do i=1,6 foo(i)
  default : do i=1,n foo(i)
end select
gain.details: The more iterations the main loop is processing, the higher the trip count must be to amortize peel/tail overhead.
gain.title: Unrolling/vectorization cost
gain.txt: This loop is peel/tail of a unrolled/vectorized loop. If its cost is not negligible compared to the main (unrolled/vectorized) loop, unrolling/vectorization is counterproductive due to low trip count.

gain.details:
93% of SSE/AVX instructions are used in vector version (process two or more data elements in vector registers):
 - 80% of SSE/AVX instructions that are not load, store, addition, subtraction nor multiply instructions are used in vector version.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is highly vectorized.
Only 24% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.

potential.workaround:
- Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
  * Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
 - Try to change order in which elements are evaluated (using parentheses) in arithmetic expressions containing both ADD/SUB and MUL operations to enable your compiler to generate FMA instructions wherever possible.
For instance a + b*c is a valid FMA (MUL then ADD).
However (a+b)* c cannot be translated into an FMA (ADD then MUL).
potential.title: FMA
potential.txt: Presence of both ADD/SUB and MUL operations.

hint.workaround:
- Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
  * Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
 - Use vector aligned instructions:
  1) align your arrays on 64 bytes boundaries
  2) inform your compiler that your arrays are vector aligned: read your compiler manual.
<<image_vec_align>>
